label.intro:
Faceting is a powerful technique in the “grammar of graphics” (Wilkinson, 2012) that enables the analyst to create a series of plots in multiple panels based on one or two factor variables. In a facet, each panel represents a different level or combination of the factor variable. Within each panel, the same choices within a plot (such as x and y variables) are repeated for each factor level (or combination of factor levels).


The analyst can choose which axes to compare the plots along, depending on the nature of the factor variable itself: If the analyst wants to compare along the y axis, then they might find they can uncover insights by faceting along the x-axis, or vice versa. This can then create comparable, repeated plots, which allows for the user to visually analyse relationships in the data across different factor levels.


Facets create a “table of graphs”, where each row or column corresponds to a specific factor level. Facets can be extended to two factors, resulting in a grid of plots, with one factor determining the rows and another factor determining the columns. This setup allows you to explore interactions and relationships between two categorical variables effectively.


Wilkinson, L., 2012. The grammar of graphics (pp. 375-414). Springer Berlin Heidelberg.
